author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Howard University Votes to Revoke Sean Combs’s Honorary Degree
description: In a unanimous decision, the university’s board of trustees also moved to disband a scholarship in Mr. Combs’s name amid investigations into abuse allegations.
content: Howard University announced on Friday that it would revoke an honorary degree that was awarded to the hip-hop mogul Sean “Diddy” Combs in 2014. The decision comes in the wake of Mr. Combs’s admission that he physically abused a former girlfriend, in addition to a slew of other allegations of abuse that have surfaced in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
title: Biden and Macron Talk Togetherness, With No Mention of Discord Over Gaza
description: The two presidents, in a brief appearance before reporters, declined to take questions, in a departure from tradition.
content: President Biden and President Emmanuel Macron of France stressed on Saturday how much they agreed with each other about world affairs, including the war in Ukraine, even as their countries have expressed sharply different views of the fighting in Gaza between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: The Napoleon of Your Living Room
description: Gary Friedman, who runs RH (formerly Restoration Hardware), is out to conquer the world, one luxurious sofa at a time. Next stop, Waterloo?
content: Gary Friedman hates meetings. A 66-year-old with apparently limitless energy and a perpetual tan, Mr. Friedman is the chief executive of RH, one of the country’s largest high-end furniture sellers, and he never holds meetings. Instead, he convenes “adventures.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily Meyer
title: An Essayist Who Revels in Glorious Chaos
description: In her third essay collection, the poet and critic Elisa Gabbert celebrates literature and life through a voracious engagement with the world.
content: “Any Person Is the Only Self,” the poet and critic Elisa Gabbert’s third collection of nonfiction, opens with an essay that should be, but isn’t quite, a mission statement. She starts by describing the Denver Public Library’s shelf for recent returns, a miscellaneous display of disconnected works she habitually browsed in the years she lived in Colorado. In part, Gabbert (who is also the Book Review’s poetry columnist) was drawn to the shelf for its “negative hype,” its opposition to the churn of literary publicity. But mainly, she enjoyed playing the odds. “Randomness is interesting,” she writes; “randomness looks beautiful to me.” At the essay’s end, she declares, “I need randomness to be happy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Stanford Becomes Latest School to Reinstate Test Scores Requirement
description: The university joins a small but growing number of elite colleges requiring SAT or ACT scores in applications once again.
content: Stanford University announced Friday that it was reinstating the requirement for standardized test scores in undergraduate admissions, becoming the latest of a small but growing number of elite colleges to go back to the practice after abandoning it during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: ‘Cheaters Don’t Like Getting Caught’: Harris Blasts Trump in Michigan
description: Vice President Kamala Harris argues that Donald J. Trump’s guilty verdict should disqualify him for the presidency.
content: In one of her first campaign appearances since former President Donald J. Trump was convicted of falsifying business records, Vice President Kamala Harris sharply criticized him on Saturday as a “cheater” who believes himself above the law and argued that he should be disqualified for the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: A Neighborhood Battles Illegal Weed Shops: ‘We’ve Been Begging for Help’
description: Alarmed by the proliferation of unlicensed stores, Lower East Side residents have banded together to track the shops and push for the authorities to shut them down.
content: Just before 11 p.m. on a recent Saturday, a young woman was buzzed into Flame Zone Convenience, an unlicensed weed store on Delancey Street in the Lower East Side displaying bags of potent gummies and multiple strains of marijuana, including one called Gunpowder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Did Politicians Break the Law by Aiding Foreign Influence Efforts?
description: A report by a parliamentary committee said that politicians, who were not named, had helped China, India and other countries meddle in Canadian politics.
content: After years of toiling away little noticed, the awkwardly named National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians certainly caught the nation’s attention this week. The committee, which reviewed 4,000 classified documents totaling 32,000 pages and held closed briefings with officials, found that some federal politicians had been “‘semi-witting or witting’ participants in the efforts of foreign states to interfere in our politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: Maya Hawke Doesn’t Want to Let the Vibe Die
description: She just finished playing Flannery O’Connor and released a new album. Next up: “Inside Out 2” and a new season of “Stranger Things.”
content: The actress and singer-songwriter Maya Hawke is on a self-awareness kick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Ballí and Thalía Gochez
title: This Glorious Celebration Shows What Border Communities Can Be
description: As the country becomes increasingly divided, Brownsville comes together.
content: The sky was muddy gray when I arrived at the Sams Memorial Stadium parking lot on a cool February afternoon. As soon as I parked, a school police officer appeared in a golf cart to rush me to the front of the parade line. I clambered aboard, one hand holding my large white Mexican sombrero rimmed with gold embroidered roses, the other scooping my thick, long skirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Lankes
title: It Called Itself a Yoga School. Prosecutors Say It Was a Sex Cult.
description: The Buenos Aires Yoga School promised spiritual salvation, but former members and prosecutors say it pushed some female members into prostitution as it cultivated powerful friends.
content: Juan Percowicz was an accountant with an unusual side hobby: teaching self-help classes around Buenos Aires with a heavy dose of ancient philosophy and New Age spiritualism. He was a hit and, with donations from his followers, he built an organization known as Buenos Aires Yoga School, or BAYS.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Affordable Housing Faces a Threat as Insurance Costs Soar
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 8, 2024.
content: “It severely impacts your operating budget. You can only squeeze a dime so many times.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Vietnam Arrests Prominent Journalist for Facebook Posts
description: Truong Huy San was accused of “abusing democratic freedoms,” a charge that rights groups say has been frequently used against critics of the government.
content: The authorities in Vietnam have arrested one of the country’s most prominent journalists and accused him of “abusing democratic freedoms” by posting articles on Facebook that “infringed on the interests of the state and the legitimate rights and interests of organizations and individuals.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Come Retribution
description: Donald Trump has a plan for his second term: retribution. We check in with the people who’ve crossed him to hear how they feel about that.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: A Gazan health official says scores are dead as Israel carries out intense bombardments.
description: Residents in central Gaza reported intense bombardments as Israel carried out an operation to rescue four hostages held since Oct. 7.
content: Residents in central Gaza reported intense bombardments as Israel carried out an operation to rescue four hostages held since Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 364, June 9, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Who Are the Four Hostages Rescued in Gaza?
description: Since the Hamas-led terrorist attack on Oct. 7, Israel has freed only a small number of hostages through military force.
content: Four hostages abducted from the Nova music festival and held by militants in Gaza for the last eight months were rescued by Israeli forces on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Praachi Raniwala
title: What Should You Wear to Our Wedding? Here’s a Mood Board.
description: Dress codes, color palettes and shopping guides: Wardrobe guidance for some weddings is getting increasingly specific.
content: When Lauren and Jackson England tied the knot with a safari wedding in Ranthambore, India, in January, they wanted the dress code to reflect the surroundings. The mood they communicated to their guests was “classic heritage Ralph Lauren.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
title: N.Y. Lawmakers End Session Without Replacing Congestion Pricing Revenue
description: State Senate Democrats rebuked Gov. Kathy Hochul over her decision to halt a long-developed plan to charge drivers tolls to enter Manhattan’s core.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul defended her decision to halt congestion pricing hours after State Senate Democrats said they would leave Albany without plugging the funding gap left in its absence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Weeks Before Prison, a Defiant Bannon Is Still Rallying MAGA World
description: The onetime adviser to former President Donald J. Trump has framed his impending imprisonment as an act of patriotism.
content: Stephen K. Bannon was sitting in the back seat of an S.U.V. on a pleasant Friday evening in Powhatan, Va., enjoying what could be his last weeks of freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: George Clooney Complained to White House About Biden’s Criticism of I.C.C.
description: The actor contacted a top official to protest the president’s denunciation of the move to seek arrest warrants for top Israeli officials over the war in Gaza, a case his wife worked on.
content: George Clooney contacted a top White House official last month to complain after President Biden criticized the International Criminal Court’s decision to seek a warrant against top Israeli officials over the war in Gaza, a case the actor’s wife had worked on, according to two people familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,086, June 9, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: An Object Lesson From Covid on How to Destroy Public Trust
description: Officials should have told us what they knew, or at least leveled with us about what they didn’t know.
content: Big chunks of the history of the Covid pandemic were rewritten over the last month or so in a way that will have terrible consequences for many years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor J. Blue and Melissa Hoppert
title: Saratoga’s Crowning Moment
description: The Belmont Stakes arrives at Saratoga Race Course.
content: Summer at the Spa — a ritual nearly 200 years strong — started early in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., with the third leg of the Triple Crown, the Belmont Stakes, being held on Saturday for the first time at Saratoga Race Course, a revered relic where the elite and otherwise mingle, but the horses rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: The Darker Side of Julia Louis-Dreyfus
description: The actress is taking on serious roles, trying to overcome self-doubt and sharing more about her personal life — but she’s not done being funny.
content: At some point in almost every performance she gives, Julia Louis-Dreyfus has this look. If you’ve watched “Seinfeld,” “The New Adventures of Old Christine” or “Veep,” you know it — the perfect mix of irritation and defiance. As if she were saying, Try me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Sarah Kessler
title: Tesla Shareholders Will Vote on Elon Musk’s Big Payday. What Happens Then?
description: The company has lobbied to reinstate the package awarded to Musk six years ago — now worth about $56 billion — after a Delaware judge voided it.
content: After months of fighting over a pay package promised to Elon Musk six years ago — one that included stock grants now worth about $56 billion — matters are finally coming to a head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gettinger
title: My Mom Had Alzheimer’s. Now I Do Too. But I Learned From Her Not to Despair.
description: A son reflects on his mother’s life with Alzheimer’s, and what it has taught him as he faces his own diagnosis with the disease.
content: My mother spent the last three decades of her life afflicted by the loss of memory and control that comes with Alzheimer’s. I remember her panicking in the night, waking my father at 3 a.m. to search for her long-dead mother. He would often give in and drive her through the deserted streets of Los Angeles to lull her back to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Raja Abdulrahim and Steve Lohr
title: Israel Rescues 4 Hostages in Assault That Killed Scores of Gazans
description: The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where tensions over the hostages’ safety have been rising in recent months.
content: Israeli soldiers and special operations police rescued four hostages from Gaza on Saturday amid a heavy air and ground assault and flew them back to Israel by helicopter to be reunited with their families. The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where anxieties over the fate of the roughly 120 remaining captives have been rising after eight months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Stand-Up Comics Are Divided Over the Growing Presence of Crowd Work
description: Crowd work has grown more common, with some comedians now focusing their acts on it and sharing clips of their exchanges with audience members. But some comics say it takes away from the craft.
content: After the comedian Joel Kim Booster performed recently at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., he posted about an interaction he had with a heckler, who was standing up and motioning a thumbs-down at Booster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Trunsky
title: What Makes Katie Ledecky Swim?
description: As she prepares for the Paris Games, the seven-time Olympic gold medalist talks about the doping accusations against her competitors and how she stays focused while swimming 1,900 miles a year.
content: Long before Katie Ledecky was collecting gold medals and setting world records, she seemed nonchalant about making it across the pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: No, Byron Donalds, Jim Crow Didn’t Create Stronger Black Families
description: The era of southern apartheid is inseparable from poverty, exploitation and violence.
content: At an event in Philadelphia promoting Donald Trump and the Republican Party on Tuesday, Representative Byron Donalds of Florida made the eyebrow-raising assertion that Black families were stronger, and Black people more conservative, under the Jim Crow regimes of the former Confederate states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Shrink the Economy, Save the World?
description: Economic growth has been ecologically costly — and so a movement in favor of ‘degrowth’ is growing.
content: A rising tide and a bigger pie: Economic growth has long been considered such an obvious boon that it’s pursued by governments across the world as a matter of course. But in 2016, when a London professor warned an audience in Newcastle that Brexit would lead to a precipitous drop in Britain’s gross domestic product, that well-worn measure of economic activity, one woman’s heckling caught him by surprise. “That’s your bloody G.D.P.,” she shouted, “not ours!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jürgen Moltmann, Theologian Who Confronted Auschwitz, Is Dead at 98
description: He drew on his experiences as a German soldier during World War II to construct transformative ideas about God, Jesus and salvation.
content: Jürgen Moltmann, who drew on his searing experiences as a German soldier during World War II to construct transformative ideas about God, Jesus and salvation in a fallen world, making him one of the leading Protestant theologians of the 20th century, died on Monday at his home in Tübingen, in southwest Germany. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: William A. Anders, 90, Dies; Flew on First Manned Orbit of the Moon
description: During the 1968 Apollo 8 mission, his color photograph of an emerging Earth, known as “Earthrise,” became an icon and driving force for the environmental movement.
content: Maj. Gen. William A. Anders, who flew on the first manned space mission to orbit the moon, the Apollo 8 “Genesis flight” of Christmas Eve 1968, and took the color photograph “Earthrise,” which is credited with inspiring the modern environmental movement, died on Friday morning when a small plane he was piloting alone dived into the water near Roche Harbor, Wash., northwest of Seattle.  He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 8, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 8, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about the start of Hunter Biden’s gun trial case misstated the middle initial of a top deputy to the special counsel, David C. Weiss. He is Leo J. Wise, not Leo P. Wise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Best Way to Get a Refund When Your Airline’s Wi-Fi Is Terrible
description: We compiled shortcuts and links for every big U.S. carrier — and some little-known tips that should make it easier to get your money back.
content: When an airline sells you a service, you should be able to receive a refund if it doesn’t deliver. But when is it not worth your time to even bother asking for one?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Vows to Lower Prices. Some of His Policies May Raise Them.
description: Donald J. Trump has not released a detailed economic plan. But three of his key proposals would push prices up, economists say.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump routinely blames President Biden for higher prices at the grocery store and everywhere else Americans shop, and promises to “fix it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: House Ethics Panel Looks Into Nancy Mace’s Use of Reimbursement Program
description: The committee will decide whether to open a formal investigation into expense reports filed by the South Carolina Republican.
content: The House Ethics Committee has begun reviewing Representative Nancy Mace’s use of a reimbursement program for lodging and other expenses of Congress members working in Washington, according to a committee member familiar with the preliminary inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
title: In Final Analysis, N.Y. Legislative Session Is Defined by Its Omissions
description: The State Legislature passed a climate bill that would force polluters to pay into a “cost recovery” fund, but the focus of the session’s last days was on the collapse of congestion pricing.
content: After a final all-night session, the New York State Legislature ended its yearly business on Saturday morning, capping a nearly six-month slog that, in the end, was defined by what failed to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: The last functioning hospitals in Gaza may soon be out of service, the health ministry warns.
description: The few overwhelmed hospitals still functioning across the Gaza Strip could be completely out of service if diesel generators needed to keep lights on and to run lifesaving medical equipment are not replaced or maintained soon, the Gaza Health Ministry warned on Saturday.
content: The few overwhelmed hospitals still functioning across the Gaza Strip could be completely out of service if diesel generators needed to keep lights on and to run lifesaving medical equipment are not replaced or maintained soon, the Gaza Health Ministry warned on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Women Rethinking Marriage and Family Life Because of Miranda July
description: The author’s new novel, “All Fours,” has spurred a whisper network of women fantasizing about desire and freedom.
content: It’s the talk of every group text — at least every group text composed of women over 40.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vicki Constantine Croke
title: The Pandas Are Back
description: The return of pandas to our zoos means more to Americans than just a burst of fleeting joy.
content: Our interest in pandas has always brought out the best and the worst in us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Peter Baker
title: Macron Hosts Biden in Paris, Honoring a Not Always Easy Bond
description: The friendship between France and the U.S. endures. But tensions have mounted over the wars in Gaza and Ukraine, and how Europe can step out of America’s shadow.
content: In the sunlight of Normandy, before the surviving American veterans who eight decades ago helped turn the tide of the war against Hitler, President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke this past week of the “bond of blood shed for liberty” that ties his country to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: University of California Workers Ordered to End Strike Over Protest Grievances
description: An Orange County judge halted the labor action by academic workers after the university system said the walkout was causing students “irreparable harm.”
content: A strike by University of California academic workers over the treatment of pro-Palestinian demonstrators was temporarily halted by a Southern California judge on Friday after the university argued the walkout was causing students “irreparable harm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Why Biden Is Right to Curb Immigration
description: His executive order limiting asylum seekers may be political, but that doesn’t mean it’s wrong.
content: Many of us liberals now find ourselves in an awkward spot on immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily C. Hughes
title: A ‘Cursed Film’ Novel, Spiked With Venom and Fear
description: Lock the windows and bolt the doors before picking up Paul Tremblay’s “Horror Movie.”
content: In his listless post-college years, the unnamed narrator of “Horror Movie,” Paul Tremblay’s new novel, is recruited by an old classmate, Valentina, for a visionary amateur movie about a group of teenage outcasts who set out to create a monster. He has no acting experience; it’s his body type — lanky and attenuated — that they want for the silent, mysterious character known as the Thin Kid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: The British Aren’t Coming. They’re Here.
description: As a historic presidential election looms, several of America’s largest and most powerful newsrooms are now being led by English journalists. Why?
content: The news business is in upheaval. A presidential election is barreling down the pike. Facing financial challenges and political division, several of America’s largest news organizations have turned over the reins to editors who prize relentless reporting on a budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Energy Drinks Boost Ukraine’s Soldiers, and Its Economy
description: Cans packed with caffeine and branded with patriotic machismo have become an essential antidote to the stresses of war.
content: On a sunny morning, deep in the forests of western Ukraine where the war barely reaches, 16,000 cans of a new energy drink, Volia, rolled off the assembly line every hour at the Morshynska beverage factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Cotto
title: How Matt Williams, the Creator of ‘Roseanne,’ Spends His Sundays
description: Mr. Williams loves people-watching and pasta with his wife. But when he’s writing on Sundays? No judgment allowed.
content: Over the past four decades, Matt Williams has been intimately involved in many of America’s most successful television programs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Will Employers Regard Today’s Student Activists?
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about college protesters’ job prospects and future careers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Kellen Browning
title: Kari Lake Delivered a Speech in Front of a Confederate Flag
description: Appearing at a Trump-themed merchandise store in Show Low, Ariz., Ms. Lake repeated lies about the 2020 election’s having been stolen from former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Kari Lake, the leading Republican candidate for Senate in Arizona, delivered a speech in front of a Confederate flag at a Trump-themed merchandise store in Show Low, Ariz., last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Quiet Time
description: Zachary Schiff’s debut puzzle moves softly, but keeps us in suspense.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Pride Month 2024: An Abundance of Theater of All Stripes
description: From Broadway to the city’s smaller stages, a flurry of shows with wide-ranging appeal, familiar faces and rising talent.
content: American theater has long been more welcoming to queer lives and stories than Hollywood has been, so the abundance of shows during Pride Month is unsurprising. It’s also overwhelming — there is just so much to see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Stage Opening, Perhaps
description: Daniel Sheremeta makes a sweeping Saturday debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent, twisty themeless puzzle that will please the solvers who pick up on subtleties and curious juxtapositions between entries. It’s Daniel Sheremeta’s second construction for The New York Times after a Friday debut in 2022; that one is another toughie that went over like gangbusters, so try it when you’ve recuperated from today’s challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: A Small American Bomb Killing Palestinians by the Dozen in Gaza
description: The GBU-39 is increasingly the weapon of choice for the Israeli military and was used in two recent mass-casualty events.
content: An American-made, precision guided bomb that homes in on specific targets and, ideally, limits civilian casualties, was used in airstrikes in Gaza that killed dozens of Palestinians, including women and children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Ronen Bergman and Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. Intelligence Helped Israel Rescue Four Hostages in Gaza
description: Intelligence collection and analysis teams from the U.S. and the U.K. have been in Israel throughout the war.
content: The U.S. provided intelligence on the hostages before Israel’s successful rescue operation Saturday, according to American and Israeli officials briefed on the assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Reyes Mata III
title: Days After Border Closes for Most Migrants, Manageable Crowds but More Anxiety
description: Shelters along the border were quieter on Friday and Saturday compared with previous months, but many hoping to cross into the U.S. felt stranded and fearful.
content: On a hot and humid morning in the Mexican border city of Reynosa, less than a mile from the Rio Grande, one question seemed to linger in the minds of hundreds of people who had arrived Saturday at a shelter for migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scare Easily? These 2 Thrillers Are Worth It.
description: Complicated sisters; messy neighbors.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Mari and Amir Hamja
title: How an American Dream of Housing Became a Reality in Sweden
description: The U.S. once looked to modular construction as an efficient way to build lots of housing at scale, but Sweden picked up the idea and put it into practice
content: As an architect, Ivan Rupnik thinks the solution to America’s affordable housing shortage is obvious: Build more houses. Start today. But the way homes are built in the United States makes speed impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: As Trump Rallies in the Southwest, Extreme Heat Threatens MAGA Faithful
description: Eleven people were treated for heat exhaustion at a recent Trump event in Phoenix. Temperatures for a rally in Las Vegas on Sunday are expected to approach 105 degrees.
content: Political campaigns do their best to control as much as possible: their candidate, their messaging, their surrogates and their schedules. But what to do about the weather?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Jordan Bardella, the New Face of France’s Right
description: Charismatic and clean cut, shorn of the Le Pen name, the young National Rally leader seems poised to take his party to its best showing ever in European elections on Sunday.
content: France has a taste for revolutions, and in the 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, it has found a mild-mannered, impeccably dressed insurgent who vows to upend the politics of the country in order to save it from “disappearance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Scores Killed in Central Gaza After Israeli Strikes, Hospital Officials Say
description: Video footage showed people running for cover as a powerful airstrike exploded near them. The attack appeared to have hit a market.
content: The Israeli operation to rescue four hostages in the town of Nuseirat in central Gaza on Saturday unleashed a heavy aerial bombardment and ground operations that killed more than 200 people, according to two hospital officials in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Who Is a ‘Rodent Man’?
description: A new term has cropped up to describe the faces of certain Hollywood actors, prompting many conversations — especially among the Styles team.
content: “Rodent Men”: What are they? Tiny men? Men who eat garbage? Some kind of furry science experiment gone wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: When the Money Is Under the Mattress. Or in the Freezer. Or a Shoebox.
description: Older people who stash large sums of cash in their homes think it’s safer there than anyplace else. But they could be creating huge headaches for their heirs.
content: After their father died in 2021, Susan Camp and her brother cleaned out his home — and inadvertently threw out $5,000 in cash he had wrapped in aluminum foil and stashed in the freezer. (Luckily, they later retrieved it.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: The Doula Has Entered the Chat
description: Many doulas, relied upon for pregnancy and childbirth support, have gone virtual. Experts say that’s a good thing.
content: Kanwal Haq, a New York-based doula, was on a plane home from a vacation last September when she received a text from her client: “It’s game day here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Scheck, Eshe Nelson and Tariq Panja
title: Washington Post Shake-Up Brings Fresh Eyes to an Old Scandal
description: The newspaper’s new publisher argued against coverage of British phone hacking. Instead, he has invited renewed scrutiny.
content: In 2011, Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, News Corporation, faced a grave threat in Britain. Reporters at one of his tabloid newspapers were exposed for hacking the phones of celebrities, private citizens and, in one case, a murdered child for information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Koba Ryckewaert
title: ‘The Bachelor,’ but Make It Belgian Politics
description: A reality show called “The Conclave” put Belgium’s political rivals together in a medieval château for a weekend. Can they put aside their differences and help keep the country from coming apart?
content: In the United States, Donald J. Trump and Joe Biden can barely agree to share a stage for a debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Swimmer Trying to Make Olympic History Is Left Off the U.S. Team
description: When the sport of artistic swimming, formerly synchronized swimming, announced it would allow men to compete in the Paris Games, Bill May saw his chance. But the U.S. team chose only women.
content: Bill May, the 45-year-old artistic swimmer who was vying for a chance to be the first man to compete in the sport at the Olympics this summer, did not make the U.S. team’s final roster, the team announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez
title: The Cats of Old San Juan Are Being Run Out of Town. Locals Can Empathize.
description: A federal plan to remove feral cats from a historic site in Puerto Rico’s capital has upset some residents, who are also feeling pushed out as housing costs soar.
content: Feral cats have roamed the blue cobblestone streets of Old San Juan for as long as anyone can remember. They meander around a historic fortress that looms over San Juan Bay, hiding from the hot sun under sea grape bushes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: I’m Choking on My Neighbor’s Smoke. But She’s Rent-Stabilized. What Can I Do?
description: When it comes to rent-stabilized tenants, legal claims against co-ops are tricky. Ultimately, it’s the apartment’s owner who must take action.
content: Q: I’m a shareholder in a large co-op in Queens. The lease prohibits odors from traveling from one apartment to another, but doesn’t include a smoke-free policy. My elderly downstairs neighbor lives in a rent-stabilized apartment and can no longer go outside to smoke. My bedroom smells like her ashtray, and I have been sleeping on my couch. The co-op’s management has sent her notice after notice for four years, and recently reached a settlement with her after threatening to bring an eviction case. They agreed that the owner of her apartment would install a commercial smoke abatement machine, but it’s been 10 weeks with no installation. What do I do now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadian Auto Parts Billionaire Faces Sexual Assault Charges
description: A police force outside Toronto said that charges against Frank Stronach, 91, relate to episodes from as long ago as the 1980s and as recent as last year.
content: Frank Stronach, the 91-year-old billionaire founder of one of the world’s largest auto parts companies, was arrested and charged on Friday in connection with a sexual assault investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isobel Lewis
title: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 6 Recap: A Charming Rogue
description: The Doctor and Ruby head back to Regency England in a meta meditation on cosplay and obsessive TV fandom.
content: For decades, cosplay has been a huge part of the “Doctor Who” fandom, with hardcore viewers rocking up to conventions or gathering to watch the show decked out in Tom Baker’s striped scarf or David Tennant’s slim suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Spiced Chicken and Rice, Extremely Nice
description: And extremely fragrant and flavorful, thanks to turmeric and cardamom, nutty roasted pistachios and sweet golden raisins.
content: I will always, in any season, make a chicken-and-rice dish. It’s my favorite protein combined with my favorite carb, and I love it in any iteration: Hainanese chicken rice, arroz chaufa, arroz con pollo, iwuk edesi, chicken perloo, chicken cook-up rice, chicken doria, oyakodon. I don’t care if it’s hot outside; all are worth mopping my brow and doing that thing where I whap the sides of my T-shirt away from my body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Sigmund Rolat, Who Used His Wealth to Memorialize Polish Jews, Dies at 93
description: A Holocaust survivor and a shipping financier, he returned to his home country, where his parents and brother perished, to help build a museum and other memorials.
content: Sigmund Rolat, a Polish Holocaust survivor who tapped the wealth he accumulated as a businessman in the United States to support cultural projects in his homeland, most notably a museum devoted to the history of Jews in Poland that stands on the grounds of the Warsaw Ghetto, died on May 19 at his home in Alpine, N.J. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Aaron Boxerman
title: Here’s How Israel’s Mission to Rescue Four Hostages Unfolded
description: The operation required weeks of planning and received the final go-ahead just a few minutes before it began, according to Israeli officials.
content: The Israeli military’s mission to rescue four hostages was a rare operation that required weeks of planning, and was given the final go-ahead just a few minutes before it commenced on Saturday morning, according to Israeli officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: President Biden’s Action on Immigration Is a Tough Sell in This Border County
description: Republicans and Democrats alike in Cochise County, Ariz., a place where many have long felt their needs are ignored, eyed the executive order with skepticism.
content: As Democrats and Republicans in Washington negotiated legislation to overhaul the asylum system and tighten border security earlier this year, many in Cochise County, Ariz., a conservative stronghold, held their breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam and Julia Jacobs
title: ‘The Time Has Come to Say Goodbye’: Pat Sajak Bids Farewell to ‘Wheel of Fortune’
description: The host thanked the show’s viewers and had special words for his co-star, Vanna White, before he signed off for the final time.
content: On Friday night, Pat Sajak said goodbye to “Wheel of Fortune,” expressing gratitude to the countless viewers who had tuned in during his more than 40 years at the helm. “Thank you for allowing me into your lives,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Sarah Lyall
title: The Best Thrillers of the Year So Far
description: These twisty suspense novels will keep you on the edge of your seat.
content: We chose the 10 best thrillers of 2023. See the complete list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Aaron Boxerman
title: A member of Netanyahu’s war cabinet who threatened to quit postpones a planned address.
description: The decision comes as Israeli authorities announced that they had rescued four hostages who had been held in Gaza since Oct. 7.
content: A key member of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Israeli war cabinet who has threatened to depart amid serious differences over the war in Gaza has indefinitely postponed an expected news conference planned for Saturday evening, citing “recent events.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: Can Big Art Make It in Las Vegas? Urs Fischer Weighs In.
description: The desert entertainment mecca is “artificial, but in a good way,” says the Swiss artist. His 46-foot-tall, gold-leaf sculpture is the city’s latest addition.
content: The Swiss artist Urs Fischer suggests beginning our day together with coffee in the Village. Not the Manhattan neighborhood of Greenwich Village — on the edge of which he lived from the mid aughts until several years ago, commuting to giant studios in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, Queens — though if you squint, there’s a resemblance to its earlier era: the maze of disorienting lanes, lots of cobblestone (sort of), neon-marqueed Italian-suggestive stands that sell iced lattes (watery) and cannolis (soggy).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli news outlets break the quiet of the Sabbath to cover the release of four hostages.
description: The main Israeli television stations have switched to live coverage of the hostage rescue, breaking the customary quiet and prerecorded programming typical of the Sabbath.
content: The main Israeli television stations have switched to live coverage of the hostage rescue, breaking the customary quiet and prerecorded programming typical of the Sabbath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Blank Screen
description: If you’ve been having trouble finding a show to watch, you’re not alone.
content: Blame it on the better weather and its privileging of being out over staying in, but I’ve been having a hard time getting into any streaming entertainment these days. I’ve started dozens of shows and abandoned them after an episode or two, never to return. Are recent shows just poor matches for my taste? Has TV become boringly mid, as my colleague James Poniewozik described? Or perhaps it’s more serious: Have I finally and irretrievably reached the outer limits of my own attention span?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Miriam Jordan
title: Biden’s Border Crackdown Could Disproportionately Affect Families
description: Parents with children represent 40 percent of migrants who crossed the southern border this year. Now, they will be turned back within days, according to a memo obtained by The New York Times.
content: A new border crackdown unveiled by the Biden administration this week is likely to disproportionately affect families, whose soaring numbers in the last decade have drastically changed the profile of the population crossing the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: What to Know About the Hostages Still in Gaza
description: Israel’s military announced it had rescued four hostages who were held in Gaza. There are roughly 120 captives still in the enclave.
content: Israelis briefly breathed a collective sigh of relief on Saturday, when the military announced it had rescued four hostages who were held in Gaza for eight months after being captured in the Oct. 7 attack led by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brenda Wineapple
title: Trump’s Most Dangerous Gift
description: For months now, he has been spinning his tale of tyranny and martyrdom, styling himself as the victim of an administration that plays dirty.
content: When a Manhattan jury found Donald J. Trump guilty, it should have sent shock waves through the nation. Yet, though the trial and conviction of a former president was unprecedented in American history, it seems most people couldn’t have cared less. As Michelle Goldberg recently noted, only 16 percent of respondents to a Yahoo News/YouGov poll said they had followed the first few weeks of the trial very closely, and when asked how they felt, many replied, “bored.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Israel Rescues Four Hostages in Operation That Palestinian Officials Say Killed Scores
description: Four hostages were rescued by Israeli forces after being held in Gaza since the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, the Israeli military said. The rescue operation in the town of Nuseirat in central Gaza unleashed a heavy aerial bombardment that killed scores, according to hospital officials in the area.
content: Four hostages were rescued by Israeli forces after being held in Gaza since the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, the Israeli military said. The rescue operation in the town of Nuseirat in central Gaza unleashed a heavy aerial bombardment that killed scores, according to hospital officials in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Mari, Gabriel Blanco, Ruru Kuo and Amir Hamja
title: Inside a Factory Where a Home Is Made Every 30 Minutes
description: The U.S. once looked to offsite construction as an efficient way to build lots of housing and drive down costs. Sweden has embraced the idea and put it into practice. Francesca Mari, a contributor to The New York Times, breaks down the process.
content: The U.S. once looked to offsite construction as an efficient way to build lots of housing and drive down costs. Sweden has embraced the idea and put it into practice. Francesca Mari, a contributor to The New York Times, breaks down the process.
source.name: The New York Times
